title: John C. Reilly
text:
John Christopher Reilly (born May 24, 1965) is an American actor, comedian, screenwriter, musician, and producer. After his film debut "<a href="Casualties%20of%20War">Casualties of War</a>" (1989), he gained exposure through his supporting roles in "<a href="Days%20of%20Thunder">Days of Thunder</a>" (1990), "<a href="What%27s%20Eating%20Gilbert%20Grape">What's Eating Gilbert Grape</a>" (1993) and "<a href="The%20River%20Wild">The River Wild</a>" (1994). He also starred in <a href="Paul%20Thomas%20Anderson">Paul Thomas Anderson</a>'s films "<a href="Hard%20Eight%20%28film%29">Hard Eight</a>" (1996), "<a href="Boogie%20Nights">Boogie Nights</a>" (1997) and "<a href="Magnolia%20%28film%29">Magnolia</a>" (1999), as well as <a href="Terrence%20Malick">Terrence Malick</a>'s "<a href="The%20Thin%20Red%20Line%20%281998%20film%29">The Thin Red Line</a>" (1998). For his performance in "<a href="Chicago%20%282002%20film%29">Chicago</a>" (2002), Reilly was nominated for the <a href="Academy%20Award%20for%20Best%20Supporting%20Actor">Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor</a> and the <a href="Golden%20Globe%20Award%20for%20Best%20Supporting%20Actor%20%E2%80%93%20Motion%20Picture">corresponding Golden Globe Award</a>. He worked with director <a href="Martin%20Scorsese">Martin Scorsese</a> on both "<a href="Gangs%20of%20New%20York">Gangs of New York</a>" (2002) and "<a href="The%20Aviator%20%282004%20film%29">The Aviator</a>" (2004).
In 2007, he starred in the comedy ', garnering him a <a href="Grammy%20Award">Grammy Award</a> nomination and a second <a href="Golden%20Globe%20Award">Golden Globe Award</a> nomination for the song performed in the film, "Walk Hard". Reilly starred with <a href="Will%20Ferrell">Will Ferrell</a> in the <a href="Adam%20McKay">Adam McKay</a>-directed comedies ' (2006) and "<a href="Step%20Brothers%20%28film%29">Step Brothers</a>" (2008). He voiced the title character in the commercially successful <a href="Wreck-It%20Ralph%20%28franchise%29">"Wreck It Ralph" film series</a> (2012–⁠2018), and appeared in the superhero film "<a href="Guardians%20of%20the%20Galaxy%20%28film%29">Guardians of the Galaxy</a>" (2014), as well as "" (2017). Reilly continued to act in independent films such as "<a href="Cyrus%20%282010%20film%29">Cyrus</a>", "<a href="We%20Need%20to%20Talk%20About%20Kevin%20%28film%29">We Need to Talk About Kevin</a>", and "<a href="Carnage%20%282011%20film%29">Carnage</a>" (all in 2011), as well as <a href="Yorgos%20Lanthimos">Yorgos Lanthimos</a>' "<a href="The%20Lobster">The Lobster</a>" (2015), and "<a href="The%20Sisters%20Brothers%20%28film%29">The Sisters Brothers</a>" (2018). In 2018 he starred as the comedian <a href="Oliver%20Hardy">Oliver Hardy</a> in the biopic <a href="Stan%20%26amp%3B%20Ollie">"Stan and Ollie"</a>. The role earned him a <a href="Golden%20Globe%20Award">Golden Globe Award</a> nomination as well as a <a href="Critics%27%20Choice%20Movie%20Awards">Critics' Choice Award</a> nomination. In 2020, he created and starred in a <a href="Showtime%20%28TV%20network%29">Showtime</a> comedy series "<a href="Moonbase%208">Moonbase 8</a>".
Reilly performs with his band John Reilly and Friends and worked as a stage actor in "<a href="True%20West%20%28play%29">True West</a>" (2000) opposite <a href="Philip%20Seymour%20Hoffman">Philip Seymour Hoffman</a>, for which he was nominated for the <a href="Tony%20Award%20for%20Best%20Actor%20in%20a%20Play">Tony Award for Best Actor in a Play</a>.
Early life and education.
Reilly was born in <a href="Chicago%2C%20Illinois">Chicago, Illinois</a>, the fifth of six children. His father was of <a href="Irish%20American">Irish</a> and <a href="Scottish%20American">Scottish</a> descent, and his mother was of <a href="Lithuanian%20American">Lithuanian</a> ancestry. His father ran an industrial linen supply company. Reilly has described himself as being mischievous during his childhood, highlighting an event when he was 12 in which he and his friends stole 500 boxes of <a href="Corn%20Pops">Sugar Corn Pops</a> from a freight train. Reilly grew up in the <a href="Chicago%20Lawn%2C%20Chicago">Chicago Lawn</a> neighborhood.
Reilly was raised <a href="Catholic%20Church">Roman Catholic</a> and attended <a href="Brother%20Rice%20High%20School%20%28Chicago%2C%20Illinois%29">Brother Rice High School</a>. He is an alumnus of <a href="The%20Theatre%20School%20at%20DePaul%20University">The Theatre School at DePaul University</a> in Chicago.
Film career.
1989–1995: Career beginnings.
Reilly made his film debut in the <a href="Brian%20De%20Palma">Brian De Palma</a> war film "<a href="Casualties%20of%20War%20%28film%29">Casualties of War</a>" as PFC Herbert Hatcher in 1989. Although his role was written as a small one, De Palma liked Reilly's performance so much that the role was significantly expanded. He played Buck, <a href="Tom%20Cruise">Tom Cruise</a>'s character's <a href="NASCAR">NASCAR</a> crew member in <a href="Tony%20Scott">Tony Scott</a>'s "<a href="Days%20of%20Thunder">Days of Thunder</a>" in June 1990. That September, he played an Irish hoodlum named Stevie McGuire in the crime film "<a href="State%20of%20Grace%20%281990%20film%29">State of Grace</a>", which starred <a href="Sean%20Penn">Sean Penn</a>; Reilly had previously appeared as a monk in the comedy "<a href="We%27re%20No%20Angels%20%281989%20film%29">We're No Angels</a>" (1989), which also starred Penn. In 1992's "<a href="Hoffa%20%28film%29">Hoffa</a>", Reilly played <a href="Jimmy%20Hoffa">Jimmy Hoffa</a>'s (<a href="Jack%20Nicholson">Jack Nicholson</a>) associate who testifies against him at Hoffa's trial. Reilly appeared in a supporting role in "<a href="What%27s%20Eating%20Gilbert%20Grape">What's Eating Gilbert Grape</a>" (1993), playing one of the titular character's (played by <a href="Johnny%20Depp">Johnny Depp</a>) friends. His next role was in "<a href="The%20River%20Wild">The River Wild</a>" (1994), in which Reilly appeared alongside <a href="Kevin%20Bacon">Kevin Bacon</a> as a pair of criminals who terrorise a family during a rafting trip. In 1995, Reilly appeared in the psychological thriller "<a href="Dolores%20Claiborne%20%28film%29">Dolores Claiborne</a>" as a police <a href="constable">constable</a> and in the drama "<a href="Georgia%20%281995%20film%29">Georgia</a>" as a drug-addicted drummer in the band <a href="Jennifer%20Jason%20Leigh">Jennifer Jason Leigh</a>'s character joins.
1996–2003: Critical acclaim.
In <a href="Paul%20Thomas%20Anderson">Paul Thomas Anderson</a>'s directorial debut film "<a href="Hard%20Eight%20%28film%29">Hard Eight</a>" (1996), Reilly played a near homeless man in <a href="Reno">Reno</a>, Nevada, who is taken under the wing of a senior gambler (<a href="Philip%20Baker%20Hall">Philip Baker Hall</a>). Reilly collaborated with Anderson on other films, playing a <a href="pornographic%20actor">pornographic actor</a> in "<a href="Boogie%20Nights">Boogie Nights</a>" (1997); a deeply religious police officer in "<a href="Magnolia%20%28film%29">Magnolia</a>" (1999); and a cameo in the music video for <a href="Fiona%20Apple">Fiona Apple</a>'s single "Across the Universe". <a href="Terrence%20Malick">Terrence Malick</a>'s ensemble war film, "<a href="The%20Thin%20Red%20Line%20%281998%20film%29">The Thin Red Line</a>" (1998) featured Reilly in a supporting role that was written as a larger one, but much of his scenes were deleted along with many other cast members. In 1999, Reilly starred in the independent film "<a href="The%20Settlement%20%281999%20film%29">The Settlement</a>" alongside <a href="William%20Fichtner">William Fichtner</a>, which "<a href="Variety%20%28magazine%29">Variety</a>" writer Robert Koehler dismissed as a "write-off" despite praising his performance. That same year, Reilly played one of the newspaper managing editors in the romantic comedy film "<a href="Never%20Been%20Kissed">Never Been Kissed</a>". In <a href="Sam%20Raimi">Sam Raimi</a>'s sports drama "<a href="For%20Love%20of%20the%20Game%20%28film%29">For Love of the Game</a>", released the same year, Reilly played fictional baseball <a href="catcher">catcher</a> Gus Sinski.
The box office hit "<a href="The%20Perfect%20Storm%20%28film%29">The Perfect Storm</a>" was his only release of 2000 and featured Reilly as a veteran crew member on the "<a href="Andrea%20Gail">Andrea Gail</a>" fishing vessel which was caught in the <a href="1991%20Perfect%20Storm">1991 Perfect Storm</a>. In the Jennifer Jason Leigh and <a href="Alan%20Cumming">Alan Cumming</a> directed comedy "<a href="The%20Anniversary%20Party">The Anniversary Party</a>" (2001), he played director Mac Forsyth. In 2002, Reilly played a stoner husband in a lackluster marriage to <a href="Jennifer%20Aniston">Jennifer Aniston</a>'s character, who cheats on him with a younger man played by <a href="Jake%20Gyllenhaal">Jake Gyllenhaal</a>, in <a href="Miguel%20Arteta">Miguel Arteta</a>'s comedy-drama "<a href="The%20Good%20Girl">The Good Girl</a>". Later that year, Reilly appeared in three of the year's <a href="Academy%20Award%20for%20Best%20Picture">Academy Award for Best Picture</a> nominees – "<a href="Chicago%20%282002%20film%29">Chicago</a>", "<a href="Gangs%20of%20New%20York">Gangs of New York</a>" and "<a href="The%20Hours%20%28film%29">The Hours</a>". In "Chicago", he played Amos Hart, Roxanne's (<a href="Ren%C3%A9e%20Zellweger">Renée Zellweger</a>) trusting husband and was nominated for the <a href="Academy%20Award%20for%20Best%20Supporting%20Actor">Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor</a>, as well as the <a href="Golden%20Globe">Golden Globe</a> for <a href="Golden%20Globe%20Award%20for%20Best%20Supporting%20Actor%20%E2%80%93%20Motion%20Picture">Best Supporting Actor</a>. Zellweger remarked that "John is so often the best thing about the movies he's in" and critic <a href="Roger%20Ebert">Roger Ebert</a> praised the "pathetic sincere naivete" that Reilly brought to the role. <a href="Martin%20Scorsese">Martin Scorsese</a>'s "Gangs of New York" featured Reilly as corrupt 19th-century <a href="constable">constable</a> "Happy Jack" Mulraney, while <a href="Stephen%20Daldry">Stephen Daldry</a>'s drama "The Hours" saw him play the husband to <a href="Julianne%20Moore">Julianne Moore</a>'s character. Reilly made a brief appearance in the comedy "<a href="Anger%20Management%20%28film%29">Anger Management</a>" (2003) as a <a href="monk">monk</a>.
2004–2011: Transition to comedy.
Reilly appeared in <a href="Martin%20Scorsese">Martin Scorsese</a>'s 2004 <a href="Howard%20Hughes">Howard Hughes</a> <a href="Biographical%20film">biopic</a>, "<a href="The%20Aviator%20%282004%20film%29">The Aviator</a>", as <a href="Noah%20Dietrich">Noah Dietrich</a>, Howard Hughes' (<a href="Leonardo%20DiCaprio">Leonardo DiCaprio</a>) trusted business partner. Of the role Reilly said, "Noah was almost a father figure to Hughes... Howard would have a scheme, and it was Noah who had to say, 'We don't have the money.' He was one of his few friends." He played the lead role in the crime film "<a href="Criminal%20%282004%20film%29">Criminal</a>" (2004), with <a href="Diego%20Luna">Diego Luna</a> and <a href="Maggie%20Gyllenhaal">Maggie Gyllenhaal</a>. Based on the Argentine film "<a href="Nine%20Queens">Nine Queens</a>" (2000), Stephen Holden of "<a href="The%20New%20York%20Times">The New York Times</a>" felt that "John C. Reilly may be one of our finer character actors, but his portrayal of Richard Gaddis, a gimlet-eyed con man, in "Criminal" allows too many vestiges of the duped schlub of a husband he played in "Chicago" to leak into his performance." Reilly reportedly quit the 2005 <a href="Lars%20von%20Trier">Lars von Trier</a> film "<a href="Manderlay">Manderlay</a>" to protest the on-set killing of a donkey. He played the lead in one of <a href="Miranda%20July">Miranda July</a>'s short films, "Are You the Favorite Person of Anybody?" (2005). He was in the <a href="Jennifer%20Connelly">Jennifer Connelly</a>-led horror film "<a href="Dark%20Water%20%282005%20film%29">Dark Water</a>" (2005) as the manager of a mysterious hotel. Reilly co-starred in <a href="Adam%20McKay">Adam McKay</a>'s comedy about NASCAR drivers entitled "" in August 2006 as Cal Naughton Jr., the best friend and teammate of the title character, played by <a href="Will%20Ferrell">Will Ferrell</a>. The film was successful, grossing $163 million worldwide. He appeared in <a href="Robert%20Altman">Robert Altman</a>'s last film "<a href="A%20Prairie%20Home%20Companion%20%28film%29">A Prairie Home Companion</a>" that same year, in addition to making an uncredited cameo appearance in "<a href="Tenacious%20D%20in%20The%20Pick%20of%20Destiny">Tenacious D in The Pick of Destiny</a>" as a <a href="Sasquatch">Sasquatch</a>.
Reilly frequently appeared on the sketch comedy program "<a href="Tim%20and%20Eric%20Awesome%20Show%2C%20Great%20Job%21">Tim and Eric Awesome Show, Great Job!</a>" from 2007 to 2010 as inept doctor and television presenter <a href="Dr.%20Steve%20Brule">Dr. Steve Brule</a>. The role led to the <a href="Spin-off%20%28media%29">spin-off</a> series "<a href="Check%20It%20Out%21%20with%20Dr.%20Steve%20Brule">Check It Out! with Dr. Steve Brule</a>", which has aired since 2010 and is written and produced by Reilly. In 2007, Reilly starred as the title character in parody bio-pic ', singing various songs, parodying <a href="Johnny%20Cash">Johnny Cash</a>, <a href="Ray%20Charles">Ray Charles</a> and others. He received two <a href="Golden%20Globe">Golden Globe</a> nominations, <a href="Golden%20Globe%20Award%20for%20Best%20Actor%20%E2%80%93%20Motion%20Picture%20Musical%20or%20Comedy">Best Actor – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy</a> and <a href="Golden%20Globe%20Award%20for%20Best%20Original%20Song">Best Original Song</a> for the film's title song "Walk Hard". The next year, Reilly reunited with Ferrell to star in "<a href="Step%20Brothers%20%28film%29">Step Brothers</a>", playing middle-aged <a href="stepfamily">step brothers</a> forced to live together. Also that year, he was among the many notable actors to perform in the online political musical, "Proposition 8 – The Musical", voiced himself in "<a href="The%20Simpsons">The Simpsons</a>" episode "<a href="Any%20Given%20Sundance">Any Given Sundance</a>", and co-starred alongside <a href="Seann%20William%20Scott">Seann William Scott</a> in "<a href="The%20Promotion">The Promotion</a>". In 2009, he played vampire <a href="List%20of%20The%20Saga%20of%20Darren%20Shan%20characters%23Larten%20Crepsley">Larten Crepsley</a> in the film ' and voiced "5" in "<a href="9%20%282009%20animated%20film%29">9</a>". Reilly starred in the 2010 film "<a href="Cyrus%20%282010%20comedy-drama%20film%29">Cyrus</a>" as a divorcé beginning a new relationship. Reilly received a <a href="Satellite%20Award">Satellite Award</a> nomination for <a href="Satellite%20Award%20for%20Best%20Actor%20%E2%80%93%20Motion%20Picture%20Musical%20or%20Comedy">Best Actor – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy</a> and an <a href="Independent%20Spirit%20Award%20for%20Best%20Male%20Lead">Independent Spirit Award for Best Male Lead</a> nomination for his critically acclaimed performance.
In early 2011, Reilly collaborated with director Miguel Arteta for a second time with the comedy "<a href="Cedar%20Rapids%20%28film%29">Cedar Rapids</a>", starring <a href="Ed%20Helms">Ed Helms</a>. "<a href="New%20York%20Daily%20News">New York Daily News</a>" critic Elizabeth Weizxman considered Reilly a stand out in the film and he received an <a href="Independent%20Spirit%20Award%20for%20Best%20Supporting%20Male">Independent Spirit Award for Best Supporting Male</a> nomination. Reilly co-starred alongside <a href="Ezra%20Miller">Ezra Miller</a> and Oscar-winner <a href="Tilda%20Swinton">Tilda Swinton</a> in the British-American drama "<a href="We%20Need%20to%20Talk%20About%20Kevin%20%28film%29">We Need to Talk About Kevin</a>", based on the <a href="We%20Need%20to%20Talk%20About%20Kevin">novel</a> by <a href="Lionel%20Shriver">Lionel Shriver</a>. His character in the film was Franklin, the father of the troubled Kevin; his performance was described as being "heartbreakingly sweet" by "<a href="Slate%20%28magazine%29">Slate</a>" critic <a href="Dana%20Stevens%20%28critic%29">Dana Stevens</a>. Next, he co-starred in the comedy-drama "<a href="Terri%20%28film%29">Terri</a>" alongside <a href="Jacob%20Wysocki">Jacob Wysocki</a>, playing a school principal who takes an interest in a teenage misfit. His last release of 2011 was <a href="Roman%20Polanski">Roman Polanski</a>'s black comedy-drama "<a href="Carnage%20%282011%20film%29">Carnage</a>", which takes place mostly in a single apartment. It also starred Oscar-winners <a href="Jodie%20Foster">Jodie Foster</a> as his wife, and <a href="Kate%20Winslet">Kate Winslet</a> and <a href="Christoph%20Waltz">Christoph Waltz</a> as another married couple who engage in a conflict after their children get into a fight. Reilly was approached to appear in a production of the play it was based on, "<a href="God%20of%20Carnage">God of Carnage</a>", but he couldn't fit it into his schedule and remarked "I think I've spent enough time in that apartment".
2012–present: Blockbuster films.
Reilly voiced the title character in the 2012 animated film "<a href="Wreck-It%20Ralph">Wreck-It Ralph</a>", which follows an <a href="arcade%20game">arcade game</a> <a href="villain">villain</a> who is determined to prove himself as the hero. Reilly made contributions to the film's script. The film was positively received, with "<a href="Los%20Angeles%20Times">Los Angeles Times</a>" writer Betsy Sharkey saying, "The movie's subversive sensibility and old-school/new-school feel are a total kick." "Wreck-It Ralph" grossed over $471 million and a sequel titled "<a href="Ralph%20Breaks%20the%20Internet">Ralph Breaks the Internet</a>" was released in November 2018. Also that year, Reilly appeared in "<a href="Tim%20and%20Eric%27s%20Billion%20Dollar%20Movie">Tim and Eric's Billion Dollar Movie</a>" as the dim-witted Taquito and made an uncredited cameo appearance in the comedy "<a href="The%20Dictator%20%282012%20film%29">The Dictator</a>", starring <a href="Sacha%20Baron%20Cohen">Sacha Baron Cohen</a>. He had a cameo in the 2013 comedy sequel "", playing the ghost of <a href="Confederate%20States%20Army">Confederate</a> <a href="General%20officer">General</a> <a href="Stonewall%20Jackson">Stonewall Jackson</a> in the film's fight scene.
In 2014, Reilly narrated the <a href="nature%20documentary">nature documentary</a> "<a href="Bears%20%28film%29">Bears</a>". He played <a href="Nova%20Corps">Nova Corps</a> corpsman <a href="Rhomann%20Dey">Rhomann Dey</a> in the <a href="Marvel%20Studios">Marvel Studios</a> film "<a href="Guardians%20of%20the%20Galaxy%20%28film%29">Guardians of the Galaxy</a>", released in August 2014. Reilly began co-starring in the animated television series "<a href="Stone%20Quackers">Stone Quackers</a>" on <a href="FXX">FXX</a> in January 2015. In addition to voicing the inept police officer Barry, Reilly also executive produced the series. 2015 saw him appear in five films: the drama "<a href="Entertainment%20%282015%20film%29">Entertainment</a>"; <a href="Yorgos%20Lanthimos">Yorgos Lanthimos</a>' comedy-drama "<a href="The%20Lobster">The Lobster</a>" as Robert, a man with a <a href="lisp">lisp</a> who is given 45 days to find a romantic partner or otherwise be turned into an animal; the fantasy horror "<a href="Tale%20of%20Tales%20%282015%20film%29">Tale of Tales</a>", in which he played a king who tries to conceive a child with his queen–played by <a href="Salma%20Hayek">Salma Hayek</a>–through an unconventional method, and the English <a href="dub%20localization">dub</a> of the <a href="Studio%20Ghibli">Studio Ghibli</a> animated film "<a href="When%20Marnie%20Was%20There">When Marnie Was There</a>". Reilly also starred in and co-wrote the television special "<a href="Bagboy%20%28TV%20special%29">Bagboy</a>", reprising his role as Dr. Steve Brule in a fictional television pilot for a sitcom created by Brule. It aired on February 21, 2015, with "<a href="Vanity%20Fair%20%28magazine%29">Vanity Fair</a>" writer Melissa Locker saying "If you get it, the show is knockout hilarious, but truthfully, it is not for everyone and Reilly is O.K. with that."
Reilly voiced a sheep in the ensemble cast of the <a href="computer-animated">computer-animated</a> musical comedy "<a href="Sing%20%282016%20American%20film%29">Sing</a>", which was released in December 2016. Reilly appeared in the 2017 monster film reboot "", as Hank Marlow, a World War II lieutenant who has spent 28 years stranded on the titular island. The actor, who described his character as "essentially a love-letter to Chicago", was singled out for praise for his performance out of what is generally considered to be an underwhelming ensemble cast. Film critic <a href="Matt%20Zoller%20Seitz">Matt Zoller Seitz</a> noted that Reilly "steals the film instantly and never gives it back" in playing the "wisecracking castaway", and <a href="Owen%20Gleiberman">Owen Gleiberman</a> praised his performance for being "terrifically dry and sly" in what could have been a cliché character.
Reilly co-starred with <a href="Steve%20Coogan">Steve Coogan</a> in the 2018 biopic "<a href="Stan%20%26amp%3B%20Ollie">Stan & Ollie</a>" about the comic <a href="double%20act">double act</a> <a href="Laurel%20and%20Hardy">Laurel and Hardy</a>, with Reilly portraying <a href="Oliver%20Hardy">Oliver Hardy</a> and Coogan <a href="Stan%20Laurel">Stan Laurel</a>. Also that year, he played hitman Eli Sisters in "<a href="The%20Sisters%20Brothers%20%28film%29">The Sisters Brothers</a>", based on the <a href="Patrick%20deWitt">Patrick deWitt</a> Western novel, with <a href="Joaquin%20Phoenix">Joaquin Phoenix</a> co-starring as his brother Charlie, <a href="Jacques%20Audiard">Jacques Audiard</a> directing, and Reilly as a producer. Reilly himself optioned the rights in 2011, and production took place in the summer of 2017. In 2018, Reilly played <a href="Dr.%20Watson">Dr. Watson</a> in a comedic adaptation of the <a href="Sherlock%20Holmes">Sherlock Holmes</a> stories, "<a href="Holmes%20%26amp%3B%20Watson">Holmes & Watson</a>"; Will Ferrell played Holmes. In the same year, Reilly reprised his role as Wreck-It Ralph in "<a href="Ralph%20Breaks%20the%20Internet">Ralph Breaks the Internet</a>". 
He made an uncredited cameo appearance as "<a href="The%20Munsters">Munsters</a>" star <a href="Fred%20Gwynne">Fred Gwynne</a> in <a href="Paul%20Thomas%20Anderson">Paul Thomas Anderson</a>'s "<a href="Licorice%20Pizza">Licorice Pizza</a>" (2021). 
Music.
In 1998, Reilly appeared, along with <a href="Giovanni%20Ribisi">Giovanni Ribisi</a> and <a href="Winona%20Ryder">Winona Ryder</a>, as <a href="Jon%20Spencer%20Blues%20Explosion">Jon Spencer Blues Explosion</a> in their video "Talk About The Blues". In 2002, he played the role of Amos Hart, <a href="Roxie%20Hart">Roxie Hart</a>'s naïve husband, in the musical film "<a href="Chicago%20%282002%20film%29">Chicago</a>". In 2006, he performed two songs on ': "Fathom the Bowl" and "My Son John". In 2007, Reilly starred in the <a href="biopic">biopic</a> <a href="parody">parody</a> '. In addition to his acting role, he also performed as a vocalist and songwriter on the movie's <a href="soundtrack">soundtrack</a>, for which he was nominated for a <a href="Grammy%20Award">Grammy</a>. Reilly went on a concert performance tour in the US, performing as his character Dewey Cox in the Cox Across America 2007 Tour.
In 2011, he recorded songs produced by <a href="Jack%20White">Jack White</a> and released as two singles by White's <a href="Third%20Man%20Records">Third Man Records</a>. The first single features two <a href="The%20Delmore%20Brothers">The Delmore Brothers</a> songs: "Gonna Lay Down My Old Guitar" and "Lonesome Yodel Blues #2", both performed with <a href="Tom%20Brosseau">Tom Brosseau</a>. The second single features <a href="Ray%20Price%20%28musician%29">Ray Price</a>'s "I'll Be There If You Ever Want" as well as the country classic "I'm Making Plans", performed with <a href="Becky%20Stark">Becky Stark</a>. He also appeared as "future <a href="Mike%20D">Mike D</a>" in the <a href="Beastie%20Boys">Beastie Boys</a>' video "<a href="Make%20Some%20Noise%20%28Beastie%20Boys%20song%29">Make Some Noise</a>". In 2012, his current band, John Reilly & Friends, was slated to perform in the <a href="Railroad%20Revival%20Tour">Railroad Revival Tour</a>, alongside <a href="Willie%20Nelson">Willie Nelson</a> & Family, <a href="Band%20of%20Horses">Band of Horses</a> and <a href="Jamey%20Johnson">Jamey Johnson</a>. However, the event was cancelled.
In 2014, Reilly appeared on the music video for <a href="Mr.%20Oizo">Mr. Oizo</a>'s song "HAM" in which he played Father. Directed by <a href="Eric%20Wareheim">Eric Wareheim</a>, "HAM" is an excerpt from the television comedy "Rubberhead", which displays sketches from various comedians. In February 2015, John Reilly & Friends performed on <a href="NPR%20Music">NPR Music</a>'s Tiny Desk Concert series. In 2017, Reilly appeared in Lil Dicky's music video for "Pillow Talking". Additionally in 2017, Reilly appeared on <a href="ASAP%20Mob">A$AP Mob</a>'s album "" as Principal Daryl Choad.
Theatre.
Reilly is known as a versatile stage actor. He has participated in numerous <a href="Broadway%20theatre">Broadway</a> productions and was nominated for a <a href="Tony%20Award%20for%20Best%20Actor%20in%20a%20Play">Tony Award for Best Actor in a Play</a> for the 2000 Broadway production of <a href="Sam%20Shepard">Sam Shepard</a>'s "<a href="True%20West%20%28play%29">True West</a>". He and co-star <a href="Philip%20Seymour%20Hoffman">Philip Seymour Hoffman</a> (after starring in "Hard Eight" and "Boogie Nights") were both nominated, alternating between the two lead characters during separate performances. From October to November 2002, Reilly starred as the title character in the musical "<a href="Marty%20%28musical%29">Marty</a>", a musical adaptation of the <a href="Paddy%20Chayefsky">Paddy Chayefsky</a>-penned film "<a href="Marty%20%28film%29">Marty</a>" (1955). In 2005, he appeared as <a href="Stanley%20Kowalski">Stanley Kowalski</a> in <a href="Edward%20Hall%20%28director%29">Edward Hall</a>'s production of the <a href="Tennessee%20Williams">Tennessee Williams</a> play "<a href="A%20Streetcar%20Named%20Desire">A Streetcar Named Desire</a>". Reilly stated in 2010 that he would be very determined to play the lead role of Nathan Detroit if a revival of the musical "<a href="Guys%20and%20Dolls">Guys and Dolls</a>" were to occur.
In March 2012, he was featured in a performance of <a href="Dustin%20Lance%20Black">Dustin Lance Black</a>'s play, "<a href="8%20%28play%29">8</a>"—a staged reenactment of the <a href="Perry%20v.%20Brown">federal trial</a> that overturned California's <a href="Proposition%208">Prop 8 ban</a> on <a href="same-sex%20marriage">same-sex marriage</a>—as <a href="David%20Blankenhorn">David Blankenhorn</a>. The production was held at the <a href="Wilshire%20Ebell%20Theatre">Wilshire Ebell Theatre</a> and broadcast on <a href="YouTube">YouTube</a> to raise money for the <a href="American%20Foundation%20for%20Equal%20Rights">American Foundation for Equal Rights</a>, a non-profit organization funding the plaintiffs' legal team and sponsoring the play.
Personal life.
Reilly married Alison Dickey, an independent film producer, in 1992 after their meeting on the set of "Casualties of War" in <a href="Thailand">Thailand</a>. They have two sons. Reilly and Dickey's eldest son Leo is a musician, who performs under the name LoveLeo. Reilly practices <a href="Transcendental%20Meditation%20technique">transcendental meditation</a>.
